TextView.android:text: Soft drinks can certainly feel like the hard option. No champagne or red burgundy for the poor driver or pregnant guest being fobbed off with a lime and soda. Considerate hosts provide more tempting options, such as elderflower pressé or cranberry juice, but at dinner that’s hardly going to complement fine cuisine. Or so I thought, until I spent a long lunch matching soft drinks with food. 'Won’t work,’ was my narrow-minded approach, mainly because of the sheer sweetness of most soft drinks. I hadn’t reckoned on Gabriel David, the owner of Luscombe organic drinks, whom I met at Mitch Tonks’ Seahorse restaurant in Dartmouth recently for a taste-off. David believes that less sweet, more natural soft drinks have every chance with food. Well, he would, wouldn’t he, and actually I didn’t like all the pairings put forward. But some convinced. For a start (and starter), mussels steamed with a herby broth were wonderful with Luscombe’s orange and lemon drink, St Clements. Chicken livers cooked with sage and aged vinegar scored a surprise hit with the Cranberry Crush – the tangy, sour red berry cutting through the liver. A plate of delicate fritto misto made a gentle, summery marriage with cool elderflower bubbly, while a richer, juicy apple and apricot blend proved a rather Moroccan combination with tender grilled lamb.
